instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Freezes on stress test, then refuses to start, works again after a while
threads.message:
We have this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> here which initally arrived with a black screen during boot.

Resoldered <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>, now it starts once, then freezes when running GeekBench. It will not turn black or anything but just freeze and needs a forced shutdown.
After that, it will always freeze while booting at around 1/4 of the progress bar.

If we let it sit for a while, it can be booted again just to freeze again on the next GPU intensive task.

We resoldered <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>, replaced <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>, replaced the GPU twice but it will not make any difference.

Any thoughts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Freezes on stress test, then refuses to start, works again after a while
threads.message: Probably VRAM issue or missing/damaged resistors around GPU/VRAM.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Freezes on stress test, then refuses to start, works again after a while
threads.message:
Thanks duke, I will check.

But can you (or somebody) help me understand why it works again after a while? Is this behavior usually caused by a heat issue or a problem with a cap not discharging or something like that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Freezes on stress test, then refuses to start, works again after a while
threads.message: It can be caused by any intermittently failing part, there's no way to really pinpoint it sadly. VRAM is the next logical step after GPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Freezes on stress test, then refuses to start, works again after a while
threads.message: It's a VRAM chip failing.... It works again after it sits because the VRAM had a chance to cool down... Kinda like how some failing graphics chips crash after rising above a certain temp... The resistance is higher in a hot chip then a cold chip so once it gets hot enough, the part of the die that is failing looses its ability to conduct electricity therefore it stops working... After it cools down, it is able to conduct electricity therefore letting it work again...
